attributes.action: Promote and enforce a legal Health Pledge for safe lifting of COVID-19 measures
attributes.background: Allow people who adhere to social distancing rules for a long time and feel healthy to return to work or school if they sign a Health Pledge that details information known to affect risk of getting or passing on infection. Shared Pledges will engender trust and keep people healthy.
attributes.additional_details: The coronavirus crisis teaches us that we need to be accountable for our health to others around us. A Pledge with legal consequences for wilful misstatement protects privacy better than track-and-trace, and allows people with low risk profiles to quickly return to a more normal existence. Employers and schools can then make reasonable adjustments to their operations, stratified by risk and tailored to their circumstances, to reduce the chance of infection transmission in their environments.

rejection.details:
We understand that you want the Government to change its approach to the lockdown, and the restrictions on certain individuals, but it's not clear exactly what you mean by a "legal Health Pledge", how people would demonsrate that they had adhered to social distancing guidance, or what legal consequences you want there to be for people making false statements in any such pledge.

The Government has made certain activities an offence during the coronavirus outbreak, although since you started your petition these have been eased, and while people are still being encouraged to work from home, you may travel to work if you cannot reasonably work from home. It is up to individual employers, not the Government or House of Commons, to decide whether employees can reasonably work from home. The Government has also announced plans for the reopening of schools for certain year groups.

You could start a petition calling on the Government to exempt certain people from the lockdown restrictions, or allow schools to reopen for certain people, but this would need to be clear about what changes you want the Government to implement.

We have published a petition calling on the Government to end lockdown to prevent further economic damage to the UK’s economy, which you might like to sign: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/315979

attributes.action: Make the SRA wave all final examinations for first year law students.
attributes.background: We are proposing that the SRA depends on our mock grades that we sat under professional exam conditions in Term 1 in order to pass/fail the core courses we need to achieve a qualifying law degree, and to implement an automatic progression to Year 2.
attributes.additional_details: As first year law students, we merely need to pass our four core modules as it accounts for 0% of our GPA. Due to COVID-19, many students are at high-risk environments and in quarantine, which is not an appropriate study environment. Therefore, we urge the SRA to take into consideration this pandemic and appreciate the unfortunate circumstances that the international students are facing by being more lenient in their requirements and waiving the compulsory final examinations for this year.

rejection.details:
Decisions about professional qualifications, including teaching, assessments and exams are a matter for individual providers, not the UK Government or Parliament.

If you have concerns about your the arrangements for a course you are on, you should raise these with the provider.

We understand that the current situation is stressful for many people, including students. Student Minds, a mental health charity for students, is collating guidance and developing resources to support students experiencing stress as a result of the current situation, which you may find useful: https://www.studentminds.org.uk/coronavirus.html

attributes.action: Stop ALL pet shops selling cages below minimum size requirements
attributes.background: The minimum size requirement for hamsters and mice is 80cm x 50cm. Pet shops sell cages that are much smaller and advice you to buy them. This needs to stop as it is against the animal welfare act of a suitable environment.
attributes.additional_details: It's unfair on animals to be in a cage or enclosure that is too small. It causes stress and sometimes death of the animal.

rejection.details:
Minimum enclosure size requirements vary from animal to animal, and for mice and hamsters the minimum cage size is 25cm by 25cm: https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/880219/selling-animals-as-pets.pdf

If you want the Government to increase the minimum enclose size for pets, including hamsters, you could start a new petition requesting this. If you want the Government to make it illegal for pet shops to advertise cages for use for particular animals, where they do not meet the minimum enclosure size requirements for these animals, you could start a new petition requesting this.

attributes.additional_details: Under this Covid-19 crisis, it is impossible for university students to reach their full potential. attributes.action: Enforce a full UK lockdown for 1 week every year to ease the effect of pollution
attributes.background: Close all non-essential services for 1 week every year. Leaving only emergency services and small corner shops open as well as essential utility services like gas electric and water plants.
attributes.additional_details:

attributes.action: Prosecute those who have created an environment for ‘profiteering’
attributes.background: The severest possible legal action to be taken against business which has taken advantage of the COVID 19 crisis, by buying up stocks to inflate prices so they can cash in on vulnerable people.
attributes.additional_details:
This immoral practice has gone against what it is to be British and has had an impact on the moral of the UK people, at a time when good moral is an essential tool in fighting the spread of COVID 19.
It is suggested that punishments should go as far as the seizing of stock and premises to be sold off, with any gains sent directly to the NHS to help combat the present crisis! 
The profiteers did not need to deliberately inflate prices and cause shortages, but they did it knowing that hardship and suffering would be inflicted on vulnerable members of society just so they could make a quick and immoral profit.
People’s lives have been put at risk and this practice goes against everything which this Country stands for, and examples need to be made.

attributes.action: Cancel University rents during the COVID-19 pandemic
attributes.background: Cancel all university final rental payments.  As advised by the government, Social distancing has been put into place to prevent the spread of COVID-19 and I am sure you are aware that a student accommodation is not an ideal environment to abide this advice.
attributes.additional_details: The effects of the new economic breakdown are already being felt throughout the country, and students are not exempt from it. As businesses and workplaces are getting shut down because of the COVID-19 pandemic, several students will no longer be able to pay the rents for their stay at the University. Likewise, on behalf of several of my University colleagues, I am asking you to pass a law for Universities to stop charging students living on their campuses for rent until the pandemic crisis ends.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/304855

attributes.action: Wipe out “owed hours” by student nurses to allow us to qualify on time.
attributes.background: I am calling for the NMC to waive any outstanding hours student nurses need to make up, by allowing us up to 100 hours of “time off” as sickness. This would SIGNIFICANTLY reduce the need for student nurses to return to practice settings they find stressful to make up an erroneous number of hours.
attributes.additional_details: Why should we be made to finish our current clinical placement and then have to return to do additional weeks to make up hours, potentially in an environment we do not want or need to be in? Potentially in environments that are damaging to our mental health?

rejection.details:
Student placements are a matter for the educational institutions the student is enrolled in, the organisation sponsoring the placement, and the regulatory bodies that are responsible for the qualifications, not the Government or Parliament.

If you have concerns about continuing with a placement you should raise these with the educational institution you are enrolled in, the organisation sponsoring your placement, and the relevant regulatory body.

attributes.action: Consider extending this academic year until December in response to coronavirus.
attributes.background: Extend this academic year until Dec 2020 (assuming that education providers are able to reopen in the Autumn), enabling pupils to return to their current schools and classes.  Start the next academic year in Jan 2021, when students will have had the chance to readjust to educational environments.
attributes.additional_details: Suddenly ending their school year will be very hard for pupils.  An extended academic year would mean pupils could come back to their current classes/schools; a familiar educational environment; with their friends; amongst teachers who know them well – with time spent getting back to where they are now academically and socially. Many will be grieving, traumatised or negatively affected in some way, they will need some nurturing to safeguard their mental health – this will equally be the case for teachers and support staff.   This adjustment would give the possibility of pupils being able to sit some of their GCSE and A level exams.  Pupils and staff would be prepared to start the new academic year, which would be shorter but more effective, in January 2021.

attributes.action: Make every County Council organise safe litter picking events during isolation
attributes.background: During this current period of self-isolation in the UK, the Government should encourage every County Council in the country to organise small, safe litter-picking events in order to reduce litter's impact on the environment in a time when it is being significantly less produced.
attributes.additional_details: While the UK faces self-isolation, the amount of litter being created in this country is likely to be much less, which makes this a great opportunity to reduce the negative effects of unnecessary plastics on our landscape, water and soil. Of course, every volunteer would be confirmed COVID-19 negative and comfortable to walk within a radius of a few miles of their home in order to pick. This would also be a good opportunity for socialisation and exercise in this otherwise isolating time.

rejection.details:
Litter and refuse collection is a matter for individual local authorities, and not the Government or Parliament. You could contact your own local authority and suggest that they organise litter collection events.

attributes.action: Protect victims of CHILD ABUSE during COVID- 19 isolation measures
attributes.background: To protect current and potential victims of child abuse during COVID- 19 isolation measures by ensuring ALL schools provide ALL children with details of relevant organisations/ charities BEFORE  schools shut.
attributes.additional_details:
Children may be vulnerable during these times by continuing to be or becoming victims of physical/ sexual/ emotional abuse.  

Times like these can lead to fear, friction and frustration especially when coupled with economic uncertainty. Children can unfortunately  become scapegoats.  

Being at home with restricted movement can be terrifying for children who are victims of abuse/ hostile home environments.

Little can be done to help child abuse victims once the school and/ or home doors close.

rejection.details:
The protection and promotion of the welfare of children is a responsibility of individual local authorities, not the Government or Parliament.

The Government has issued guidance for schools and other educational settings, including on safeguarding and vulnerable children and young people: https://www.gov.uk/government/collections/coronavirus-covid-19-guidance-for-schools-and-other-educational-settings

Most schools and colleges have now closed to most students, so it would not be possible for the Government to update its guidance to recommend that schools issue certain information before they close.

If you are worried that a child or young person is at risk or is being abused the Government has published guidance on how to report this: https://www.gov.uk/report-child-abuse

You can find out more about coronavirus and how you can protect yourself and others here:

NHS website: https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/coronavirus-covid-19/
UK Government website: https://www.gov.uk/coronavirus

You can read NHS tips to help if you are worried about coronavirus here: https://www.nhs.uk/oneyou/every-mind-matters/coronavirus-covid-19-anxiety-tips

attributes.action: For Environmental awareness to be made compulsory and a module within Schools
attributes.background: For all schools to apply a core module from early years on the Environment encouraging awareness and action. It can be a fundamental initiative which encourages young people to engage in their environment by being educated on climate change fit for each school year.
attributes.additional_details: Environmental education is essential to ensure our future generations apply the measures required to preserve our environment. Bringing nature to the classroom is imperative to highlight to school children (and parents indirectly) the need for change. Environmental awareness and nature should be on a par with key classes in all schools. It is essential that children grow up with a great understanding, education in current issues and knowledge on what actions to take to protect earth.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/300279

attributes.action: Close nightclubs and bars to prevent spread of COVID-19
attributes.background: Nightclubs and bars are possibly the worst environments for coronavirus to spread. By closing them for an appropriate amount of time will result in a safer, healthier UK during this pandemic.
attributes.additional_details:
Working in a nightclub myself, I am worried for my own and for other’s safety. Whilst closing schools and universities is also important, I believe that nightclubs and bars are a greater risk to health.
Here’s some reasons why:
-Drinking alcohol lowers the immune system.
-There is a large capacity of people in a small space.
-There are people passing germs by sweating, couching, kissing and many more
-While intoxicated, people are more likely to forget to wash their hands.

rejection.details:
Since you started this petition, the Government have announced further measures for social distancing, including closing bars and nightclubs. You can read more about this here: https://www.gov.uk/government/news/government-announces-further-measures-on-social-distancing

attributes.background:
I want a complete ban on the production and sale of plastic dog poo bags. 
As a keen environmentalist they are obviously a huge problem for me, wildlife and the environment.
attributes.additional_details:
I want a complete ban on the production and sale of plastic dog poo bags.
